website_summaries.verdict: While not for everyone, if you can get comfortable with these, you'll love them for their steadiness and high level of adjustability.
pros: Comes in 2 sizes: original and compact
A lightweight, adjustable option that attaches to your sunglasses
Stays in alignment well and gives you a large, steady field of view
cons: Can be difficult to mount on sports or cycling glasses
Some may have trouble adjusting to having a mirror attached to their sunglasses

customer_reviews.title: Best rear view mirror
customer_reviews.text: Don't waste you're money on the handle bar mounted mirrors, these are awesome. It's so much easier to see behind you by just turning your head than trying to turn the handle bars. I would recommend that you have a pair of glasses just used for riding with these attached. I had been removing and storing them inside my helmet between rides, but they are thin and fell through the vents in my helmet and were lost.
customer_reviews.author: Cotterpin

customer_reviews.title: Converted
customer_reviews.text: Been using the mirror now for quite some time, it has significantly improved my feeling of security. It takes some getting use to, to train yourself to slightly turn you head, glance into the mirror and focus. After awhile it becomes almost second nature. I've clipped my mirror(s) onto a pair of ordinary tinted safety/shooting glasses.
customer_reviews.author: UnregisteredTop Contributor: Photography

customer_reviews.title: Defective mirror not returnable!
customer_reviews.text: The mirror looks like it should work well, but the mirror itself is defective. It has an area of scratches. I am a Prime member and attempted to return it, and was told that this item is not returnable. Very disappointing!
customer_reviews.author: Harlene

customer_reviews.title: Sunglasses mount vs Handlebar mirror? Sunglasses is far superior.
customer_reviews.text: With a 15 percent increase in cyclists hit by (texting) drivers in the last year, and growing, I bought these and a handlebar mirror for my road bike after 30 years of riding without feeling the need. This stays put and firm on my sunglasses. While I doubt any are perfect, this does the job. Yes, you can turn at an intersection without having to glance back, with 100 percent certainty you are safe. That's pretty cool. The handlebar end mounted mirror btw was crummy in all aspects. You'd need to stare REAL hard to see anything because it's so far way, and the vibration makes it worthless.
customer_reviews.author: J. Warner

customer_reviews.title: Good field of view. Light and simple.
customer_reviews.text: I loved this easy to use rear view mirror, where I could see what was coming up on me without moving my drop bars or trying to adjust my legs. Easy to adjust yet stayed on without a problem to my dedicated cycling glasses. Only downside was an accident where my "face first fall" put the mirror apparatus into the brow of my left eye. 9-stitches later I am just grateful I was wearing glasses. I still want to reorder because this was the lightest and easiest rear-view mirror I have found for cycling on my road bike.
customer_reviews.author: Chad M.

customer_reviews.title: Regrettable
customer_reviews.text: This is, without a doubt, the dumbest thing I have ever bought. There is really no way to adjust it so that you can clip it to your glasses and see what's behind you. You can see your helmet, maybe. Or if there is a way to adjust it so that it's not silly, I wouldn't know, because mine broke immediately before I could even get on the road. I thought it was worth a try. Nope. Back to a bike mounted mirror, and I'm glad I didn't send too much money figuring out what I could have guessed from afar.
customer_reviews.author: Eric L.

customer_reviews.title: Maybe it will work for you.
customer_reviews.text: A lot of people use this mirror. A lot of people recommend it. I am not one of them. I tried to make it work, but for me it never did. It drove me nuts. I gave it three stars, just because it's well made and the maker has a good reputation. But I have to tell you, it was a great day when I switched mirrors (to Zefal, btw) and was able to take this thing off my helmet. It's a wonderful thing to be able to look at the world without this little gizmo dangling in front of you.
customer_reviews.author: G. Taylor

customer_reviews.title: Tried others - This is still the best.
customer_reviews.text: The trick is to turn it carefully at the "twistable joints" & bend it at the "non-socket angles" to get it to exactly where it works for your eyes & your glasses. I set the mirror in a "diamond angle" & adjusted it so I can see cars without turning my head. It never vibrates because the arm is short. (I purchased the normal length.) This is my 2nd mirror. (Someone sat on my first.) I experimented with several other kinds of mirrors but came home to purchasing this again. By exactly imitating the bent angles of my 1st mirror, I was able to set this new one correctly in 30 seconds.
customer_reviews.author: Christine Kari

customer_reviews.title: Won't fit on Oakley glasses
customer_reviews.text: I really REALLY wanted this to work. I read some very favorable reviews for the Bike Peddler mirrors and was anxious to try them. However, I wear prescription sunglasses and they are Oakley Flax 2.0. The arm on the glasses is far too big for the mirror to mount to them. I even called the manufacturer and they seemed to know about this problem. Nonetheless, the people at Bike Peddler were great. For customer service, I would give the 5-stars. But for the fit on Oakleys, the mirror wont work.
customer_reviews.author: C-Dub

customer_reviews.title: Not as described in product catalog
customer_reviews.text: The length of the arm from mount to mirror is hardly enough to extend beyond your face - hence not at all convenient to get a good view of the road behind. The product does not fit easily on the cycling goggles, and most helmets. If you try returning through the Amazon locker, to avoid going out during these Covid times, Amazon still insists you to print their return label which ensures you go out to Staples or OfficeMax to print and expose yourself unwantedly. Common Amazon, you need to think how this can be done without all the additional printing of return labels etc.
customer_reviews.author: CS

customer_reviews.title: Impossible to adjust
customer_reviews.text: Thought this was a good idea. I adjusted this to fit to my helmet, which took some time to figure out. It just doesn't work. You can get it stabilized, but you cannot get a steady image because your head isn't stable when you are riding. In the time it takes to figure out what you're looking at you could just turn around for a second. Very disorienting. Wish there were something effective, but I haven't found it. This thing takes much too much work and provides no appreciable benefit.
customer_reviews.author: NeilB

customer_reviews.title: Hindsight is 20-20
customer_reviews.text: After dealing with handlebar-mounted mirrors for far too long, this glasses-mounted solution is ideal. Wherever your head is, the mirror is there, too. Incredible adjustable, and completely non-obtrusive. I got the standard/original version, not the short/compact one, and it feels just right. Folds up and stores nicely in the case for my riding glasses. If you don't wear riding sunglasses, this might not be the solution for you, as I think it would be challenging to get a great mount on a visor or other part of the helmet. But for mounting on glasses, it's superb, and highly recommended.
customer_reviews.author: PerryD

customer_reviews.title: Mounted on my helmet, it's jiggly but...
customer_reviews.text: It's the easiest way to have a mirror on my Brompton folding bike. It vibrates and requires fairly regular fiddling as it changes with every little head movement. It's about what I expected but it securely fits my helmet visor and a little zip tie keeps it secure. I tried it on my sunglasses but it works better on the helmet for me. If there was a 3.5 star rating, that's what I would give it. I found no better choice out there for this sort of mirror. I bought the compact version at the same time but it was simply too small to be useful to me and I returned it.
customer_reviews.author: Chris

customer_reviews.title: Great Mirror
customer_reviews.text: I have used this mirror for about 7 years now. The unit I bought all those years ago is still in perfect condition. I use it on every bike ride. It gives me a sense of security. I wanted to buy a 2nd mirror for a friend who is getting into biking. I was a little disappointed with the new mirror because the wire is visible inside the mirror piece. On my old mirror the wire is not visible so 100% of the mirror area is clear. Size is the same on the old as in the new mirror. I took off one star for this reason.
customer_reviews.author: JO

customer_reviews.title: Fantastic!
customer_reviews.text: I have the original and love it. It was fine when I had it on my glasses, but they are quite lightweight and this mirror, while not exactly heavy, was enough to make them sit a little crooked. I mounted it to my helmet visor with a couple of zip ties instead and have been a happy camper ever since.
customer_reviews.author: John Sledd

customer_reviews.title: a necessity
customer_reviews.text: Attaches to a helmet easily. I saw that one person had trouble with it slipping, so I used a small strip of velcro around the little fingers and have not had any problems with slippage. It is adjustable in all directions, very easy to use! I've had a handlebar mounted mirror, but the bike vibration made it difficult to see. With the helmet mount, the vibration is greatly reduced. I also attached a small piece of reflective tape on the outside/back side of the mirror....every little bit helps to be seen. No more turning around to see behind, causing possibly dangerous swerving. Wouldn't ride without it!
customer_reviews.author: MMB

customer_reviews.title: Great safety device.
customer_reviews.text: This little mirror makes Biking MUCH safer. It's easy to tilt my head a bit to scan behind and me for approaching vehicles. No more surprises from cars crowding the bike lane or trucks hugging the shoulder. No more twisting around to see behind me. It attaches easily to either my glasses or my helmet. It's easy to adjust, and it stays where I set it. I was a little concerned about how easy it would be to see in a mirror so close to my face, but it is not a problem.
customer_reviews.author: MG

customer_reviews.title: Useful after a stroke
customer_reviews.text: This mirror helps a lot since I lost my left side peripheral vision due to a stroke. I used to use it while riding my bike but now this handy mirror really increases my range of vision while I'm walking in public. I no longer bump into people because I can see them approaching from behind me instead of them just appearing all of a sudden. For me, it's a great adaptive tool that helps me feel safer and more confident as I go through my day.
customer_reviews.author: Avdotya

customer_reviews.title: Great Little Mirror
customer_reviews.text: I settled on this mirror after trying several bicycle mirrors. This mirror is flat and you get a realistic view of what is behind you. I mount it to my eyeglasses as I wear them all the time. I tried, without success, to mount it on my helmet. It takes a little getting used to as far as adjusting the mirror correctly and learning to tilt our head slightly. I wear bifocals so I have learned to tilt my head down slightly. Once you get the hang of it, you can see what's behind you with just a quick glance to the side. Would definitely recommend.
customer_reviews.author: Edward Winchester

customer_reviews.title: The Best of his type... Buy it
customer_reviews.text: When i received the item, i was surprised by how small the mirror was... However, after using it, attached to one of my glasses legs, i was impressed how big, the field of view is. The one problem that i found with this mirror, is that it cant be used with a visor. I use it with my prescripción glasses, and the mirror attached to a pair of big sunglasses that act as a visor. Very recomendable, and after already using another Brand of helmet mirror, this one is the Best!!!
customer_reviews.author: geronimo

customer_reviews.title: It's unique, and fills a niche nicely. Very durable.
customer_reviews.text: I bought my first one and almost gave up on it. I finally figured out how to mount it by watching some youtube videos (it is really easy to mount, so easy that I couldn't figure it out...I'm a computer guy). Very durable, I have dropped my helmet a few times and everything on the mirror swivels and pivots and it's easy to align with any helmet, head or glasses. Since then I have bought several for friends and relatives. It's a real safety tool so you can see traffic behind you and if riding with a partner, you can manage pace so you can stay together (my wife likes that).
customer_reviews.author: Picky Consumer

customer_reviews.title: Takes some getting used to but better than other options
customer_reviews.text: This is not perfect by any means. I have tried every which way and it all depends on the position of the head so you could have it perfect but as soon as you move your head, it's gone. So you have to get it pretty close to your riding position (being careful not to run into anything while you're doing it) and then learn to move your head slightly when you want to take a look behind you. It's not as good as a motorcycle style mirror that's stationary alas for bikes that's not a good option.
customer_reviews.author: Doctor C

customer_reviews.title: Requires A Learning Curve
customer_reviews.text: I went back and forth between this one and the Safe Zone by EVT. Since this one was less cost I tried it first and was hopeful. It's easy to install, easy to adjust and well made. But it does require some getting used to. The mirror surface is very small and it was hard to find the right spot during a ride. Closing my right eye helped but I got tired of doing that pretty quick. If the mirror were larger I'd probably have kept it but as it is I found the Safe Zone easier to use. See my review on that one.
customer_reviews.author: John A. Sorrentino

customer_reviews.title: don't ride without it!
customer_reviews.text: This is the third one of these I've owned, not through any fault of theirs, but due to me losing and/or breaking them. I feel so much more aware of my surroundings wearing this. Let the bike snobs thumb their noses at me...better Fred than dead I say! I tried the compact version and didn't care for it, so when I lost it on a ride, I replaced it with the tried and true classic version. I've ridden without the mirror a few times, and I definitely feel less safe. None of my local bike shops carry these anymore for some reason, so thanks Amazon!
customer_reviews.author: Jeff W.

customer_reviews.title: Buy this one!!! not a plastic one.
customer_reviews.text: I first started using a rear view mirror in 1983 when I first started training to race bikes. The first one I had was from Bike Nashbar when they first started. It was made out of a metal bike spoke but worked for years. It was the type that clipped to my cycle cap. Ok, stopped wearing those caps so I had to start with the cheap plastic mirrors for the helmet. They are crap! Finally found this one. It works great. You can bend this one to fit the sports glasses. The plastic ones will just break. Don't waste your money on the cheaper ones, this is the best.
customer_reviews.author: J. P. Dunbar

customer_reviews.title: Buy this mirror!
customer_reviews.text: I've been using this mirror for a month now, bicycling to work and home again every day. I highly recommend it. It's small enough to not create a big blind spot, but it's large enough to see traffic behind you easily. The eyeglass attachment thing hooks easily and firmly to my biking sunglasses without needing tape. They've never shaken loose even when I've biked over curbs or other rough terrain. For the cost, these are an EXCELLENT product.
customer_reviews.author: ZZZman74

customer_reviews.title: Great rear view once you get it adjusted
customer_reviews.text: Works well as a rear view, It can be a little finicky but once you have it adjusted it’s really nice to be able to see what’s behind you. I have it on my helmet visor have to be careful when you put your helmet down because you can easily break it and it does move around a bit. So you have to identify the points of attachment once that’s done it really is great. Not only can see what’s directly behind you but you can see well to either side by moving your head.
customer_reviews.author: G. McGrath

customer_reviews.title: It works!
customer_reviews.text: I love being able to have more of a view behind me. I had no idea how to attach this to my glasses and had to google pics. Seems an image on the package wouldn't be too much to expect, but these are lightweight, adjustable, provide a good view and reasonably priced. I wonder how long they will last going onto and off of my glasses every day. At this time, I think I would replace them when they do stop working (which I hope is a long time from now).
customer_reviews.author: B. Smith

customer_reviews.title: Takes some getting used to, but definitely helpful
customer_reviews.text: This is a great solution for when I'm on one of my bikes that doesn't have another mirror. It is a bit hard to use since it's small and fairly close to my face, but it works well for taking a look at what's behind me when riding around town. I didn't like having it on my glasses, too close to be able to focus easily, but it works well on my helmet visor. I am glad I went with the larger size, the small one would be too close for me.
customer_reviews.author: Julie Thomas

customer_reviews.title: Works, but annoying
customer_reviews.text: Well, this works for seeing traffic behind you. However, I wish it were more secure. The main problem I have is that I'm ALWAYS knocking it off my helmet. When I'm on the bike, stopped to put on or take off layers of clothing or simply when I'm moving the helmet around in my room with the mirror attached. Even if you slightly bump it, you have to readjust it. I wish there was a way to SECURELY mount it to the helmet visor. Other than that, you will likely need to bend it out some in order to see primarily the road behind you and not your own ear and neck.
customer_reviews.author: Casey526

customer_reviews.title: Simple and Effective design.
customer_reviews.text: This did not work for me. Couldn't get it to fasten to my helmet, but it did clip onto my sunglasses. I found it distracting trying to look a the mirror to see behind me and I had to move my head "just so" hence my 3 stars. Personally I like the handlebar type mirrors ,better functionality for me, but I do see others that have successfully mastered the helmet mirror. Definitely worth giving it a shot to see if it works for you.
customer_reviews.author: Bchmn53

customer_reviews.title: Finicky.  Hard to keep in adjustment
customer_reviews.text: I found this hard to securely attach to my helmet. As others suggested, I used cable straps to secure it. But even with those straps the mirror itself is hard to keep adjusted so you can see what's coming. In fact, you have to turn your head to see traffic behind. So unless you are constantly looking for cars, they will be crawling up your rear before you know they are there. In addition, the mirror is very small. This was a waste of money.
customer_reviews.author: TertiumQuid

customer_reviews.title: The best mirror
customer_reviews.text: Great mirror! You won't regret it. Very well built. Very adjustable. Easy to install. If you've never used a mirror like this here's a tip for getting it adjusted quickly every time. I mount the mirror to my glasses (Iv'e seen others mounted to the helmet) I adjust the mirror so I see the edge of my ear. This gives you a reference point that never changes. This way with a slight turn of your head to the left you can see behind you easily. Takes a little getting used to, but it's not hard. Put your helmet on, put your glasses on, adjust the mirror to see the edge of your ear and you done.
customer_reviews.author: Hankdoink

customer_reviews.title: Good Rear View for Bikers
customer_reviews.text: I really like this mirror - far better than the mirror that attached to my handlebar which isn't very wide (electric bike). Thcce mirror attaches easily to my regular glasses but is more difficult to attach to my googles. Still, the rear view is great and that was my objective.
customer_reviews.author: MR PHIL BOWLING

customer_reviews.title: Life In The Fast Lane
customer_reviews.text: I recently purchased both an Original Take A Look and a Compact Take A Look Mirror to clip on the side piece of my cycling glasses. Initially I didn't think the Compact version would give me enough depth of field, but surprisingly I much prefer the Compact version and will be ordering a second one as a back up. Don't get me wrong, the Original is also nice, but I don't need that large of a mirror blocking part of my field of vision. The Compact version is now my "go to" mirror. Nice to be able to take a quick glance and see if anyone is coming up behind me. Great product!
customer_reviews.author: Hardcore Harley

customer_reviews.title: Handy and inexpensive rear view mirro
customer_reviews.text: These come in a short or long size. They were out of the long size and I wanted one fast so I got the short one. In the end, I think I might go for the longer one. The short one is very close to your eyes so generally you will only see from the one eye, whereas I think the longer one may be easier to focus using 2 eyes? The mount was perfect for my prescription glasses I wear, and it stays put well. Easy on and off and compact.
customer_reviews.author: Grainne Hed

customer_reviews.title: Pleasantly surprised
customer_reviews.text: I had my doubts, but ordered this anyway, trusting the good reviews. I was pleasantly surprised on my first trip out with it. I had no problem mounting the mirror on my glasses, and am not concerned about damaging the frame, or the weight. It's easy to adjust, and I usually move my head slightly anyway when I look for traffic behind me. I didn't notice any vibration issues. I even like to use it off-road (see photo), since other cyclists are usually faster than me :-)
customer_reviews.author: R. ALLEN

customer_reviews.title: Eyes in the back of my head. Terrific Rearview!
customer_reviews.text: Okay I just got this. May update after my bicycle trip this weekend. But my initial reaction is good. This works! I will never go mirrorless again. It's like I have eyes in the back of my head. I attached it to NoCry Safety Glasses. Both are great. I took a pic in the mirror to give you an idea. I can totally see behind me. I no longer feel safe riding without it.
customer_reviews.author: Carmen 'n Seattle

customer_reviews.title: Well made but won't fit on my Oakleys
customer_reviews.text: These work OK on a regular set of eyeglasses but are next to useless on cycling glasses such as Oakleys. They simply do not fit. I tried zip tying them to a helmet but could not get them in a position where I could see the mirror. The compact size seems to have a shorter arm which makes placement even more difficult.
customer_reviews.author: Dave M

customer_reviews.title: Decent Mirror
customer_reviews.text: I attached mirror to my riding glasses. It does take time to learn how to use this mirror. Pros: I can see what is behind me. With practice, mirror becomes easy to adjust Lightweight Company will replace a broken mirror for a nominal cost With practice, it is easy to install Cons: It makes you look like a dork. I can see what is behind me (if a car is too close, what you see is terrifying) The mirror sometimes changes position (rotates) by itself. It does vibrate a little, but it is not bad.
customer_reviews.author: M. C.

customer_reviews.title: Unable to get it adjusted to be within my field of view
customer_reviews.text: I use bicycle safety eyeglasses with the curved frame and I was unable to get the mirror into a position where I would see it through the eyeglass. It might have worked had the frame been longer as with their helmet model. I opted for the Specchio Eyeglass Mounted Cycling Mirror which is considerably more expensive but provides a superior design developed by an avid cyclist in Arizona.
customer_reviews.author: WinterTop Contributor: Photography

customer_reviews.title: Decent for dog walking
customer_reviews.text: I'm not a cyclist, so these were purchased for dog walking. The mirror is a little small for this purpose and does bounce around a little as I move my head (I secure the mirror to a baseball cap) while walking, but all in all, they do the trick of making me feel a little safer from traffic as I walk my boys. The manufacturer offers a great replacement and/or breakage policy with the purchase.
customer_reviews.author: coachtim

customer_reviews.title: Much better than a handlebar mounted mirror
customer_reviews.text: This Mirror provides a very good view of what's behind, much better than the handlebar mirror I had before. I have the standard length and size mirror which works great. The compact one would be to small for me, and a shorter one would not work well for me either. I mounted the mirror on my glasses with the prongs up (see picture), this puts the mirror in a good position to the side. There mirror stays on snuggly, and does not bounce or shake. Plus this is made in America, sadly one of the very few things that still is.
customer_reviews.author: Ann

customer_reviews.title: Need ability to adjust the mirror to the left and right
customer_reviews.text: I originally despised this mirror because it can only be pivoted up/down and not left/right. The arm of the mirro has to be bent left/right for that adjustment. However, once bent and set, this mirror with a short arm shows a clear and stable image. I did buy another mirror with a long arm, and that thing bounces up and down so much during riding that the image from the mirror is a blurring mess.
customer_reviews.author: Chitown388

customer_reviews.title: Fell Off -- Waste of Money
customer_reviews.text: I bought this for my son to use because he rides to school on some streets with heavy traffic. He tried it for the first time today... and it fell off somewhere. Gone. We had it mounted on the helmet visor and it had felt pretty secure. The mounting system is difficult to attach, but clearly comes off very easily. Poor design. Now he's back to having no mirror and I'm out the cost of the darn thing.
customer_reviews.author: Rob Clayton

customer_reviews.title: This mirror seems to work better than any other mirror i have tried
customer_reviews.text: This mirror seems to work better than any other mirror i have tried. I ones that stick on the helmet don't seem to fit right. Maybe it was my helmet? The ones that fit in the end of the handlebar loosen up and fall out. i have tried the ones that clamp on the handle bar like a motorcycle, they work but they don't extend far enough to get a good view behind you. You end up seeing most of yourself in the mirror. Good warranty. Made in the USA!, Colorado. No negatives noted......
customer_reviews.author: Allen E.Horila

customer_reviews.title: Most important to know is what’s behind you so you can change lanes safely.
customer_reviews.text: This is the only kind of mirror I use. Unfortunately the rubber (?) coating on the three prongs tends to fall off at times. I wish they would think of a process to keep this from happening. I’ve tried wrapping a rubber band around it but doesn’t work all that well.
customer_reviews.author: David B

customer_reviews.title: It surprised me how well it works. It does ...
customer_reviews.text: It surprised me how well it works. It does take some time to get used too. Learning how and where to mount it takes some practice and different areas until you find one that works for you.. Using it is similar is to the method of learning how to aim and shoot with both eyes open. But even when I forget a quick shut of one eye and I have a clear view. If I break or lose them I will get another one. Matter of fact I should do that now so I have a spare one.
customer_reviews.author: themess

customer_reviews.title: Compact version -- it has my vote!
customer_reviews.text: I have used the "original" version for years, and it has been a great mirror. My "original" was getting a bit weak at the mirror/frame junction, so decided to order another -- and give the "compact" version a try. That proved to be a great move. As well as I liked the original, I now prefer the compact version hands-down. I have just as much view, but it "feels" better due to not sticking so far out front of my glasses. I've recommended the brand as long as I've used the original version, but the compact version now has my vote.
customer_reviews.author: therater

customer_reviews.title: Tougher than it looks
customer_reviews.text: This is a solid block of acrylic mirror on a metal stalk. I had one for years before getting this one for my son. Works well on glasses, or mount it to the helmet itself, with a zip tie for permanence. You may have to pick which side it is on based on how it folds, rather than to favor your dominant eye. But it is great to know in an instant what is behind you, so you are safer on the road.
customer_reviews.author: David G Carter

customer_reviews.title: No more helmet mounted mirrors for me
customer_reviews.text: I had no idea these existed until I came upon this on Amazon. For some reason, I didn't think it would work well. I had just broken my helmet-mounted mirror that I wasn't crazy about, and I wanted to try something else. These were absolutely perfect. I will honestly never use a helmet mirror again. The mirror stays in place the entire ride, and is perfect for what I needed.
customer_reviews.author: Alisha Gammon

customer_reviews.title: Constantly falls off.
customer_reviews.text: I love the clarity and adjustability of this mirror. What I don't love is the way this thing fell off my freaking visor constantly. In fact, it fell off, probably literally for the 20th time this evening and I just let it in the street. I have two other mirrors and both adhere to the helmets instead of using this retarded friction-clipping mechanism and neither has had this problem. This design might work great clipped to the bridge of glasses, but I obviously don't have the time or patience to babysit this insipid thing to make sure it stays on my helmet.
customer_reviews.author: Jason

customer_reviews.title: Great for long rides, not so good for city intersections
customer_reviews.text: I bought this for a multi-day, many miles ride with a large group of people. It was important to be able to check back for cars and other cyclists before passing. One day I didn't have it with me, and got a sore neck from turning back so much. After the long ride, I took it off but kept instinctively looking for the mirror even though it wasn't there. It does take some getting used-to, but once you do it's worth having. However I don't recommend it for city riding, because it does block one eye's forward view. This becomes distracting as you approach an intersection, and cars ahead to your left may be obscured.
customer_reviews.author: Charlie G

customer_reviews.title: A must have for cyclists
customer_reviews.text: This is a must have for any cyclist, I have been using this brand for years, never failed and works perfect, I bought a new helmet and immediately bought this for it, I really can't ride anymore without this mirror. Make sure you give it some time to get used to using it (very important) because it will feel weird initially. I also use tie wrap and attached it to the helmet vs using my sunglasses, it just feel better, highly recommended.
customer_reviews.author: MJ

customer_reviews.title: Very short stem
customer_reviews.text: I tried to mount this on my wraparound style sunglasses and they would not fit over the frame close to the front of the glasses. This put the mirror to close to my eye to see around my helmet. No way I can figure out how to use it with the sunglasses. Previously I had a brand that had a round mirror but the stem was longer so it worked.
customer_reviews.author: roger raydon

customer_reviews.title: Get the bigger one
customer_reviews.text: After repeatedly experimenting with adjusting the angle of these, I could, on a completely straight road, do a partial head turn and glance in these and see what was behind me. But there is so little viewing area I never felt safe relying on the view. And forget it on any incline or a curved road- I had to do the whole head turn to feel safe. Maybe the bigger ones are more functional.
customer_reviews.author: CoolBeans

customer_reviews.title: Small, effective, unobtrusive mirror
customer_reviews.text: The mirror mounted on my Specialized helmet visor. It took a few tries to get it in just the right spot. I need to adjust it when I first put my helmet on, but it doesn't shift around when riding. It would be nice if it were a little bigger, but I chose a small mirror for the reason that it's small and unobtrusive. It does it's job well and stays put as expected.
customer_reviews.author: TomG

customer_reviews.title: Works great
customer_reviews.text: To me, this is the key to safe bicycling--being able to see what is coming up from behind. Some of my friends say that they cannot get used to using a mirror but I have had no issues. Because I can see behind when I turn my head, I can see people riding behind me and to either side of me. I rarely ride without this mirror and when I have, I felt naked. I bought several of these as gifts and spares (although I have never damaged mine).
customer_reviews.author: M. Lau

customer_reviews.title: Assistance Taking the lane
customer_reviews.text: It's taken quit a while getting used to and adjusting the mirror correctly. Once I did that it has helped with seeing the breaks in traffic when taking the lane can be done in a careful, respectful manner. BTW, there are two mirrors with different wire lengths and mirror sizes available. I like the larger and longer wire length.
customer_reviews.author: David Fitch

customer_reviews.title: USELESS to runners
customer_reviews.text: This might work for cyclists or walkers, but is useless for runners--the mounting is so flexible that the mirror bounces up and down--if you try to use it, you'll be nauseous in twenty feet and still have no idea what's coming up behind you. I'm giving mine to a neighbors kid so he can pretend to be a superhero whose superpower is seeing behind him.
customer_reviews.author: lewes

customer_reviews.title: Clear view, holds adjustment, works w/skinny frames.
customer_reviews.text: I've owned several "Third Eye" mirrors over the years. They work, but frequently need re-adjustment, and never hung onto the skinny metal bows of my prescription glasses. I always had to wear plastic sun glasses to give them a wide-enough bow to mount on. Then I tried this one. What an improvement. The (slightly larger) flat glass mirror is crystal clear, and once adjusted stays in place. It works on my metal framed prescription glasses. However -- it won't work on some plastic sunglasses with fat frames. I love it, but your mileage may vary.
customer_reviews.author: Dennis Frey

customer_reviews.title: Makes You a Safer Rider
customer_reviews.text: Surprise. This thing works. It can take a little adjustment and getting used to but it's a huge help. I'd heard a lot of people trash these helmut mirrors but my bike class instructors swear by them. This makes me a safer rider.
customer_reviews.author: S. Gowin

customer_reviews.title: Give it 5 rides
customer_reviews.text: Easy to install and secure. I have no clue why so many people have such problems installing it, it takes me about 6 seconds and it doesn't budge until I want to take it off again. Give it 5 rides. Don't get frustrated and take it off and throw it away. Your brain will figure out how to use it and then it is a great asset to have on the road.
customer_reviews.author: Eve McFallen

customer_reviews.title: Works like a charm
customer_reviews.text: Just like the other reviews, I agree with: 1) the metal wiring keeps its shape and will less likely to break compared to their competitors w plastic wiring. 2) the original version has slightly a longer length to focus on the mirror with. I prefer a mirror on the handle bar but since my newer bike has wider handle bars this bike peddler brand is an alternative recommendation.
customer_reviews.author: lokie242

customer_reviews.title: Easy to adjust on the fly.
customer_reviews.text: Adjustability is three-way and very easy to do while riding. Also really like the ease of mounting to glasses. I use two different pairs of glasses when cycling and they have ear pieces of very different thicknesses. Rather than run the risk of eventually breaking the mirror mount, by bending it back and forth when changing from one pair of glasses to the other, I just bought a second mirror. At this very reasonable price it just seemed like a better option.
customer_reviews.author: The Big Lug

customer_reviews.title: Great item
customer_reviews.text: Works! What a difference it makes for me. Attaches to my regular glasses or sun glasses when I choose not to wear regular glasses. You can see behind you, making lane changes much safer. Since I have no vision in one eye, it is allows me to check traffic without any problems. Intend to get another one soon for a back up. Well worth the money.
customer_reviews.author: RWS

customer_reviews.title: ... the regular size for several years and its the best mirror i have ever used
customer_reviews.text: I have had the regular size for several years and its the best mirror i have ever used. I lost the rubber pieces that attach to the frame and a big bump shook it off my glasses and it got lost. I reordered the "compact" size and found the viewing and overall smaller size much better for road bike riding. I highly recommend the compact size.
customer_reviews.author: JAMES DAY, Jr.

customer_reviews.title: Enhanced riding safety.
customer_reviews.text: I am so glad I found this item. It is by far the most practical rear view mirror for cycling. Like others in the reviews, I zip-tied it to my helmet. It stays in adjustment and it's just perfect. No more neck yoga while trying to maintain balance on the bike. Clarity is excellent. Build quality is very nice. Once this mirror is adjusted you can see everything you need to behind you with just slight cocking of your head.
customer_reviews.author: R. Ilano

customer_reviews.title: Works great and very adjustable
customer_reviews.text: Really am beginning to like this mirror. It does take a long time to get it into a spot where I am happy with it, and I admit I'm still futzing with it.... but it is so adjustable. the one drawback is that is really is designed to go on your eyeglasses. I actually can kind of get it clipped onto the front visor of my bike helmet, but it really wasn't designed to be hung from there. has good field of vision. One thing I learned is to put it closer to your eye than you originally might have thought, so that it can give you a bigger field of view to the rear.
customer_reviews.author: Mister Dubya

customer_reviews.title: Easy and Secure
customer_reviews.text: How did I ever ride without one of these mirrors?! I bought the smaller of the two versions and I love it. It does not obstruct my view and really does help monitor what's going on behind me. Really makes me feel more secure watching the traffic that's about to pass me. Takes a bit of getting used to the perfect position on your glasses and adjusting the mirror, but once you find the sweet spot it works perfect!! Would buy again!!
customer_reviews.author: Farrah Bauer

customer_reviews.title: Husband loves it!
customer_reviews.text: My husband cycles an average of 300 miles a month, and loves this mirror. He never rides without it. His friends love it as well. It is small enough to be out of the way but safe for him to be able to ride on highways/busy areas. When he bumps it he has some trouble getting it back to the exact position he likes, but says this is one of the best accessories we've purchased for his bicycle.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Perfect accessory
customer_reviews.text: I bought both compact and original. I returned the original as it felt a bit too vision blocking, as it blocks out a larger section of your view, obviously. The compact is great. It takes some time to get used to it and angled right, but absolutely perfect for checking hindsight easily and knowing when a car is coming. It took a bit to get it mounted right and fitted on the glasses, but seems to fit tightly.
customer_reviews.author: FilmComposer

customer_reviews.title: Works well and won't fall off.
customer_reviews.text: I had a helmet mirror I liked but the tape didn't stick after a few months and it would fall off between rides. When I opened the package with this mirror, I wasn't too sure about it- it's pretty small and flimsy looking. But it attached to my helmet visor securely and provided a good rear view. Best of all, no worries about the mirror unsticking mid-ride. So far I'm very pleased with it.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Not as easy as it might appear
customer_reviews.text: Mirror is lightweight and robust - stays on sunglasses. Only 4 stars because instructions are cryptic and hard to understand. I looked on YouTube for video and still installed the mirror incorrectly on my sunglasses. Had to have cycling buddies help me. Requires minor tweaks to get the mirror itself angled just right to see traffic behind you.
customer_reviews.author: SkiGirl

customer_reviews.title: The mirror and mount seem pretty sturdy.  More serious riders though may want a convex mirror
customer_reviews.text: I was able to clip this onto my helmet visor pretty easily. I think it could probably stay in place decently with out any help, but I did wind a thin strip of electrical tape around it to ensure it stayed put. My bike routes have very few heavy traffic situations so I just wanted a little "helper" to see what was coming up from behind. I think if you commute you may want to get a convex style mirror to ease use and improve visibility
customer_reviews.author: Terri

customer_reviews.title: Ordered two - one was great the other broken
customer_reviews.text: I ordered two of these, one for my husband and one for me. Mine is great, I feel much safer while I cycle. My husband’s came with one of the metal pieces half the length, so would not work as designed. We figured out how to rig it, but would send it back if it happened again. Make sure to check all pieces are as they should be before throwing away packaging so you can return if needed
customer_reviews.author: Wahine

customer_reviews.title: Quality has gone down since a few years ago
customer_reviews.text: I bought one of these mirrors for myself several years ago, and I still love it. However, I just got one for my son, and it seems the wuality has gone down. On the recently-purchased version, the metal piece that connects to the mirror actually lies in front of the reflective surface and obscured the view. Note that in my picture the older mirror is on the left, and the reflective surface is completely unobscured. I understand that this often happens the longer an item is on the market: the producer finds a cheaper manufacturer and quality goes down. It’s sad that you can’t buy something a second time and expect consistent quality. I will be returning this item.
customer_reviews.author: Knox in Box

customer_reviews.title: One of the two best bike mirrors I know
customer_reviews.text: This glasses-mounted rearview mirror gives an excellent view of the street behind, and best of all it does not go out of alignment when I go over a bump in the road. The only mirror I found superior to this is the EVT Safe Zone bicycle mirror, but that is helmet-mounted and therefore provides less flexibility in use.
customer_reviews.author: A Reader in Virginia

customer_reviews.title: couldn't make it stay on my helmet
customer_reviews.text: I couldn't get this to attach to my helmet. The instructions are not very detailed and it would be nice if they included a picture.
customer_reviews.author: J

customer_reviews.title: I like it
customer_reviews.text: This really works great. The best part is, it's much lower profile than some of those big dorky mirrors you might have seen. I know some of the other reviews talk about how the mirror slips, and I guess it does... a little. Maybe I'm just used to fidgeting or adjusting my glasses, but I think it's such a minor thing. No need for velcro or anything, just push it back into place. Great mirror. I feel much safer on the road now. Thanks.
customer_reviews.author: Ryan P. Long

customer_reviews.title: Good luck making it work on wrap around sunglasses
customer_reviews.text: I tried to make this mirror work on two different wrap around sunglasses. A waste of money. If you have a cheap pair of flat front glasses like the orange pair in the customer pics, you will be all set. But if you have a nice pair of wrap around sunglasses, stay away.
customer_reviews.author: Tim W.

customer_reviews.title: Mounted on Helmet Visor and used small zip tie to securely mount it
customer_reviews.text: Several reviewers complained of mounting problems. But several other reviewers suggested a small zip tie to securely hold the mirror mount arm. The zip tie worked. After some fiddling with aiming mirror while riding bike on quiet streets it seems to be useful as an added safety device.
customer_reviews.author: Seeking Solutions

customer_reviews.title: Why did I wait so long?
customer_reviews.text: This mirror is better than anything I've used in the past. I ride with many others on a somewhat regular basis, and see many wearing this mirror. I've only used Chinese crap the local stores sell. This is proudly made in the USA! The mirror seems bigger and gives me a clearer view behind me than any other mirror ever has, and making adjustments is stiff, so the mirror tends to stay in place once it's set. This product makes my road riding safer. I'm a happy camper :)
customer_reviews.author: Tim

customer_reviews.title: An essential product
customer_reviews.text: This is an essential product for anyone who regularly rides a bicycle, especially in an urban setting. I clipped the mirror onto my glasses, it is easily adjustable. It provides an excellent view of the road behind me and to my left, so if I have to maneuver because a bike lane is blocked, I can do so without blindly swerving or having to turn my head wildly. I initially had a problem setting it up and customer service was excellent to resolve the issue.
customer_reviews.author: Baron von S.

customer_reviews.title: simple, light weight, easy to use, and tough
customer_reviews.text: Simple, efficient and very stable mounted as instructed. It takes some getting used to regarding shifting your focus range and turning your head very slightly. That's my experience anyway. It's been durable through two minor crashes as well (not my finest moments) and hasn't been damaged at all. You can't go wrong.
customer_reviews.author: Ardubt

customer_reviews.title: A necessity IMO. Great mirror
customer_reviews.text: Love this thing. I just used gorilla tape to hold it on to my helmet and that works fine. I guess if i rode more than one hour at a time the heat in the summer would melt the adhesive and make a mess, but i don't do long-ass rides. You can basically ALWAYS know what's behind you without cranking your head around and risking getting your steering off or crashing from hitting a curb or whatever.
customer_reviews.author: Clay Ferguson

customer_reviews.title: It's like having eyes on the back of my head
customer_reviews.text: I won't ride without it, it's like having eyes on the back of my head. It's excellent, small enough to not be distracting, but big enought to see cars passing you. I adjust it so that I can see the lane on the left when in a neutral position and can see straight behind me by just moving my head a tiny bit.
customer_reviews.author: Juliana Peña

customer_reviews.title: Not as pictured
customer_reviews.text: Was not as pictured on the website or on the packaging. The telescoping wire to adjust distance from the wearer’s glasses extended all the way was half the length pictured in the ad and package. Returned for refund. (Amazon’s refund procedure worked well)
customer_reviews.author: Edward Book

customer_reviews.title: Works great
customer_reviews.text: These are much better than the black plastic round ones found in most bicycle shops. I have been cycling for over 20 years, and in my opinion this are great for helping you be aware of what is coming up behind you. There is a wide one and a narrow mirror. I prefer the wider one.
customer_reviews.author: Chuck G.

customer_reviews.title: Excellent coverage of what’s approaching from behind
customer_reviews.text: This mirror attached to glasses is more stable and has less vibration than Helmet mounted mirrors. The adjustments possible to get the best rear field of vision are also better than helmet or handlebar mirrors. The re-elected images are perfectly clear and not wavy.
customer_reviews.author: Babs Adams

customer_reviews.title: Compact is true!
customer_reviews.text: When they say compact, they're not kidding. Really well built and, for the price, useful and functional. I followed up this purchase with one that velcros to my helmet and sticks out in front of my face. This one is so close to my head that I have to look "over" to the left to look into the mirror. Not bad....but I think keeping my eye straight ahead is safer. I will definitely keep this one as a backup...and will probably be my mirror to travel with.
customer_reviews.author: Russ

customer_reviews.title: Would be impossible to commute in Los Angeles without one of these
customer_reviews.text: It would be impossible to commute in Los Angeles without one of these. When I forget it, I feel blind. The frame is very sturdy and flexible. Conforms easily to any kind of frame: from thick to thin, from rigid to flexible. I tend to put it on thick framed sun glasses in the morning and then move it to very thin and flimsy clear (3M eye safety type) glasses at night. It bends back and forth without a problem. I have dropped it several times, cold/hot and wet/dry weather for over 3 years without a problem (i bought my first mirror in a bike shop, bought two on amazon as a gift)
customer_reviews.author: J.M.

customer_reviews.title: WOW!
customer_reviews.text: All I can say is WOW! I just was not expecting so much from such a small, simple item. These are easy to apply to any sunglasses/visors, and the image is so clear. Very easy to adjust and no, it is not in the way while biking. I wear it on my left side as I ride on the left side of the road. With just a glance and a slight turn of my head, I can see clearly behind me with NO distortion (as this is a flat mirror). I cannot recommend this enough to anyone reading this and trying to decide whether to purchase or not...just get it!
customer_reviews.author: Randy RowellTop Contributor: Cycling

customer_reviews.title: Great Cycling Mirror!
customer_reviews.text: Received yesterday and used this morning on a road ride. Easy mount on left stem of my glasses. An adjustment here and there to get the mirror angled right, but once adjusted, no movement other than a small amount of vibration on rougher road surfaces, and in any event, easy to see rear traffic without turning my head. I am going to order another for backup.
customer_reviews.author: Howard S

customer_reviews.title: Best Bicycling Safety Item for the Buck
customer_reviews.text: Just bought this one for my wife. I've used one for three years and I feel naked without it. This clip on mirror is a must-have safety item for a cyclist that rides on the road. Worth every penny of its price. The clip-on feature doesn't work as well on sports glasses with wide temples, but a simple rubber band or a small rubber band made from a small inner tube placed over it fixes this small annoyance.
customer_reviews.author: Tony B

customer_reviews.title: These metal devices are so much better than other plastic versions which break easily
customer_reviews.text: These metal devices are so much better than other plastic versions which break easily. I've had this pair years and they continue to work great. The only concern is that the rubber gaskets can easily come off when taking the mirror off your glasses - requires dilligence to ensure that the gaskets are not lost. Having a rear mirror is a must for any cyclist. At least you'll know if/when you're about to be hit from behind.
customer_reviews.author: G. Marino

customer_reviews.title: After cycling for the last 10 years, I've found perfect mirror.
customer_reviews.text: Perfect mirror,, just the right size. (purchased smaller version) I like seeing approaching cars from the rear when cycling. Went on a ride without it recently and will never do that again. Mirror is very easy to adjust and will more reliable than the plastic mirrors I had purchased in past.
customer_reviews.author: BRIANBURGETT

customer_reviews.title: Falls Off & Lost from Helmet
customer_reviews.text: I was riding this morning on a paved pathway around a local lake as I and many have for years, I decided to get a rearview mirror a few weeks ago, I soon found I appreciated the safety factor it afforded, this morning when riding it fell off the helmet at some point, terribly disappointed and disgusted!!
customer_reviews.author: Dale E. Land

customer_reviews.title: A bit too small
customer_reviews.text: I purchased the compact version because I was planning to mount on my sunglasses. However, the support stems are so short that I can barely extend them enough to get the mirror into view. Also, the mirror itself is so small that it is very difficult to get it into position to make the view useful. I have been using for a few rides now and i is better than nothing, but think I should have gotten the standard size.
customer_reviews.author: Brisguy

customer_reviews.title: Perfect for recumbent bikes and trikes!
customer_reviews.text: I had one of these many years ago when I had a road bike. Due to the hunched-forward riding position and road noise transmitted through the bars, it wasn't very useful and I gave up on it. Fast forward to a new recumbent tadpole trike and their total lack of possible mirror mounting positions. I figured that I should give these another go. It works so well that I ordered a another for my wife to use on her trike. I highly recommend them for those that have upright or laid-back seating.
customer_reviews.author: Ward M.

product_meta.title: Bike Peddler Take A Look Cycling Eyeglass Mirror
product_meta.description:
This unique cyclist's mirror has 3 pivot points for total adjustment. Fully adjustable lightweight rear view mirror, can be fitted to either eye glasses or a helmet visor. Mirror face is adjusted by rotating at a 90 degree angle from the wire, and rotates fore and aft for the fine angle adjustments. The mirror has a wide field of vision. It can be attached to either your eye glasses or helmet visor. Adjusts to fit on right or left side. Frameless acrylic mirror provides wide, uninterrupted field of vision. Three point attachement system adjusts for a secure fit without vibration. Made in USA. Features: Three pivot points for total adjustability Wide field of vision Durable stainless steel & brass frame with an optically correct acrylic mirror  

AMAZON.COM
Unique and extremely usable, the Bike Peddler Take A Look Cycling cyclist's mirror easily fits on helmet visors and eyeglasses. With three pivot points for maximum adjustment, the mirror face is adjusted by rotating it at a 90-degree angle from the wire. The mirror rotates fore and aft for fine angle adjustments. An ideal tool to keep an eye on traffic approaching from behind, the frameless acrylic mirror provides a wide, uninterrupted field of vision.

 For added adjustment, the mirror is designed to fit on both the right or left side, and its 3-point attachment system adjusts for a secure fit without vibration. Available in two sizes: compact, which extends 50 millimeters and has a mirror size of 20x37 millimeters (HxW) and normal, which extends 85 millimeters and has a mirror size of 28x37 millimeters (HxW). Made in the USA, this mirror is backed by a manufacturer's unconditional guarantee.
feature_bullets: Versatile, vibration-free cycling mirror mounts on eyeglasses and helmet visors
Three pivot points for total adjustability
Frameless acrylic mirror provides a wide, uninterrupted field of vision
Adjusts for both left- and right-side use
Made in USA; backed by a manufacturer's unconditional guarantee
